content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This will definitely reward clashers who start writing code without wasting time reading the long introduction text ;-)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very long description that could definitely be simplified, but the problem is well described overall and (just) solvable in 5 minutes.

The "NO SUCH KEY" part makes it a bit harder than is probably necessary, but it helps differentiate this from similar existing clashes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Accidentally removed my previous approval, its a nice creative challenge that fits well within the bounds of a CoC while still being intuitive

Input
* Line 2: Please add "(negative)" and "(positive)" after "left" right "left" respectively. (Currently they aren't explicitly stated except as notes in examples.)

Cases
* Validator 4: Please delete the trailing newline in the input.

Thanks.

I agree the description is rather long, maybe I should cut out the context paragraph (starting with "As Michelle is just starting out...")?

Also, which other clashes are similar to this one? Am interested to know :)

Yes, that paragraph could at least be shortened to something that just explains about the [[move]] operation.

Here's a site that allows you to search for existing clashes:
https://codingame.tools/?q=%22C%20C%23%20D%20D%23%22

Transposing a list of notes at once:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/66369e7e38b50d2b881a250e624cbf32cd1e

Transposing notes but without octave numbers and with 1 = whole tone:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/6954ceb8370da883c9d0aca1c4ea66427543

Transposing notes but without octave numbers, shift defined by two input notes and with different black key names:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/20739e7af87e7682761095576937ba9196bba

Transposing Chords:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/6035df0618299a1005f0bd4494932507a829

Making Chords:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/18051c16c141b1115b57493c3d8f6a86c10c

One thing I noticed when I just played this now in Shortest mode is that it's not actually clear from the statement that the octave number changes from B to C. I naively coded a solution assuming that it went from A0, ..., B0 to C0, and then increasing only when you reach A1.
It would be useful to mention "Octave numbers increase with every C note, with the first five notes being "A0 A#0 B0 C1 C#1".

The description has this line: "The next note after B is C (the next octave)."
Example 2 in the description also shows stepping down from C3 to B2, while example 3 shows stepping up from B7 to C8.

Yeah, it just didn't feel very clear to me in-clash is all. Even though I had solved it before and have learnt it before too. I imagine for people with no music knowledge it would help to have it spelled out for them since it's natural to assume there'd be a C0. "The next note after B is C (the next octave)" doesn't quite seem to make it clear enough to me, maybe "The next note after B is C (the next octave: B0 -> C1)." would be an easier change?
Sure, let me add that in.
